Routine surveillance following surgical removal of cardiac mass
Cross-sectional imaging or other clinical findings highly suggestive of cardiac mass

To guide specified treatment decisions (e.g. Mavacamtem septal ablation pacemaker etc)

Significant change / progression (e.g. new NYHA Class III or IV symptoms) since last echo

Suspected inherited cardiomyopathy - abnormal examination ECG and/or or other positive findings

Established genetic or infiltrative cause of LVH - no change in clinical status and/or echo <12 months ago

Crescendo anigina (exertional increasing frequency and/or severity)

Confirmed NSTEMI (partial thickness infarct) - ECG changes and/or troponin rise
Typical angina (exertional with classic character/location) -  CTCA also requested

Fluid balance assessment: prior to comprehensive clinical assessment and initial management

Outpatient: Significant change in symptoms (e.g. new NYHA Class III or IV) no echo in 12 months (BNP not required)

Assess sesponse to change in treatment (BNP not needed)

Outpatient: Clinical signs + BNP 400-2000

Clinical signs but BNP <400 (and no other cardiac findings to warrant echo for other reason)
Peripheral oedema only no other cardiac findings BNP not provided

Re-assesment for response to treatment (after >1 week of antibiotics)
Repeat assessment in clinically stable patient with known vegetations

Where echo will not help guide treatment (e.g. already fully anticoagulated for other reason)
